dt.t: the ingenuity of destruction … had outrun the {wi}ministry{/wi} of healing

dt: {bc}the office, duties, or functions of a {a_link|minister}
{bc}a person or thing through which something is accomplished {bc}{sx|agency||}, {sx|instrumentality||}

dt.t: heroic believers become such by the {wi}ministry{/wi} of heroic pain

dt: {bc}the period of service or office of a minister or ministry

dt.t: Many reforms were enacted during his {wi}ministry{/wi}.

dt: {bc}the body of ministers governing a nation or state from which a smaller cabinet {dx_def}see {dxt|cabinet:1||3b}{/dx_def} is sometimes selected
{bc}the group of ministers constituting a cabinet
{bc}a government department presided over by a minister
{bc}the building in which the business of a ministry is transacted

et: Middle English {it}ministerie, minstri{/it} "personal service, religious office, position in a church," borrowed from Middle French & Latin; Middle French {it}ministere{/it} "service, duty," going back to Old French, borrowed from Latin {it}ministerium{/it} "activity of a servant, duty, task, support" (Late Latin, "ecclesiastical service") from {it}minister{/it} "servant, {et_link|minister:1|minister:1}" + {it}-ium,{/it} denominal suffix of occupations
shortdef: the office, duties, or functions of a minister
the body of ministers of religion : clergy

dt: {bc}religious leaders as a group {bc}ministers as a group

shortdef: religious leaders as a group : ministers as a group

dt: {bc}the chief minister of a ruler or state
{bc}the official head of a cabinet or ministry
{bc}the chief executive of a parliamentary government

shortdef: the chief minister of a ruler or state
the official head of a cabinet or ministry; especially : the chief executive of a parliamentary government
